articles.headline: Tough Path Seen by Obama on Ban of Assault Weapons
articles.snippet: President Obama pledged to crack down on what he called “weapons of war,” but the White House is emphasizing other measures it deems more politically achievable.
articles.abstract: President Obama pledged to crack down on what he called “weapons of war,” but the White House is emphasizing other measures it deems more politically achievable.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — While President Obama pledged to crack down on access to what he called “weapons of war” in the aftermath of last month’s schoolhouse massacre, the White House has calculated that a ban on military-style assault weapons will be exceedingly difficult to pass through Congress and is focusing on other measures it deems more politically achievable.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Nokia Has Some Good News After Two Years of Gloom
articles.snippet: Nokia, the erstwhile leader in mobile phones that was once teetering on the brink of irrelevance, may be on its way back thanks to strong sales of its new smartphone line.
articles.abstract: Nokia, the erstwhile leader in mobile phones that was once teetering on the brink of irrelevance, may be on its way back thanks to strong sales of its new smartphone line.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly two years ago, Stephen A. Elop, Nokia’s new chief executive, spoke of flaming ocean platforms and shark-infested waters to describe the problems he inherited as the company teetered on the brink of irrelevance.

articles.headline: Clouds Seen in Regulators’ Crystal Ball for Banks
articles.snippet: The models used to assess financial risk are still flawed, according to a new report from a Treasury Department agency, the Office of Financial Research.
articles.abstract: The models used to assess financial risk are still flawed, according to a new report from a Treasury Department agency, the Office of Financial Research.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five years ago, the financial regulators of the United States — and more broadly the world — didn’t see the storm coming.

articles.headline: In Second Look, Few Savings From Digital Health Records
articles.snippet: The conversion to electronic records has failed so far to reduce health care costs, according to a new study by the RAND Corporation, which issued a rosier report in 2005.
articles.abstract: The conversion to electronic records has failed so far to reduce health care costs, according to a new study by the RAND Corporation, which issued a rosier report in 2005.
articles.lead_paragraph: The conversion to electronic health records has failed so far to produce the hoped-for savings in health care costs and has had mixed results, at best, in improving efficiency and patient care, according to a new analysis by the influential RAND Corporation.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: In Tighter Loan Rules, Wiggle Room for Banks
articles.snippet: Federal regulators, apparently concerned about doing anything to disrupt a recovering housing market, allowed mortgage lenders big concessions in a new slate of regulations.
articles.abstract: Federal regulators, apparently concerned about doing anything to disrupt a recovering housing market, allowed mortgage lenders big concessions in a new slate of regulations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Homeowners got their first big chance to judge the fledgling regulator charged with policing abusive lending after the introduction of a broad set of mortgage rules on Thursday.

articles.headline: Geithner’s Tenure Defined by Financial Crisis
articles.snippet: As he looks back on a tumultuous tenure, Timothy F. Geithner, the Treasury secretary, is remarkably sanguine.
articles.abstract: As he looks back on a tumultuous tenure, Timothy F. Geithner, the Treasury secretary, is remarkably sanguine.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a matter of days, the nation’s Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, will leave the department he first joined more than two decades ago and re-enter private life for the first time since he was in his 20s.

articles.headline: As Nurse Lay Dying, Offering Herself as Instruction in Caring
articles.snippet: A nurse terminally ill with cancer volunteered to be a subject of research for students from her alma mater.
articles.abstract: A nurse terminally ill with cancer volunteered to be a subject of research for students from her alma mater.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOUTH HADLEY, Mass. — It was early November when Martha Keochareon called the nursing school at Holyoke Community College, her alma mater. She had a proposal, which she laid out in a voice mail message.

articles.headline: Bank Deal Ends Flawed Reviews of Foreclosures
articles.snippet: As quick justice, regulators are giving cash payments to 3.8 million borrowers, but the deal is actually a way to paper over a deeply flawed review of foreclosed loans across America.
articles.abstract: As quick justice, regulators are giving cash payments to 3.8 million borrowers, but the deal is actually a way to paper over a deeply flawed review of foreclosed loans across America.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal banking regulators are trumpeting an $8.5 billion settlement this week with 10 banks as quick justice for aggrieved homeowners, but the deal is actually a way to quietly paper over a deeply flawed review of foreclosed loans across America, according to current and former regulators and consultants.

articles.headline: Errors Mount at High-Speed Exchanges in New Year
articles.snippet: The United States’ 13 public stock exchanges have been competing to offer the fastest and most sophisticated trading software, creating more opportunities for technology errors.
articles.abstract: The United States’ 13 public stock exchanges have been competing to offer the fastest and most sophisticated trading software, creating more opportunities for technology errors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Confidence-shaking technology mishaps have been an almost daily occurrence at the nation’s stock exchanges in the new year.

articles.headline: France Battling Islamists in Mali
articles.snippet: France answered an urgent plea from the government of its former colony to help blunt an advance into the center of the country by Islamist extremist militants.
articles.abstract: France answered an urgent plea from the government of its former colony to help blunt an advance into the center of the country by Islamist extremist militants.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAMAKO, Mali — The international standoff with Islamists controlling northern Mali took a decisive turn on Friday, as French forces engaged in an intense battle to beat back an aggressive militant push into the center of the country.
articles.byline: By Adam Nossiter and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Regulators Will Review Boeing 787s for Safety
articles.snippet: Federal authorities said they would order an examination of electrical systems in Boeing’s new 787 Dreamliner after a spate of incidents, including a battery fire this week in Boston.
articles.abstract: Federal authorities said they would order an examination of electrical systems in Boeing’s new 787 Dreamliner after a spate of incidents, including a battery fire this week in Boston.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal authorities on Friday ordered a comprehensive review of electrical systems in Boeing’s new 787 Dreamliner after a spate of incidents, including a battery fire this week in Boston, 15 months after the technologically advanced aircraft came into service.

articles.headline: Wells Fargo’s Mortgage Gains May Be Unsustainable
articles.snippet: Wells Fargo earned $5.1 billion in the fourth quarter, up 24 percent from the previous year, but continued growth depends on lower interest rates or a stronger housing recovery.
articles.abstract: Wells Fargo earned $5.1 billion in the fourth quarter, up 24 percent from the previous year, but continued growth depends on lower interest rates or a stronger housing recovery.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Peter Eavis
